alice.goal: Provide my availability for scheduling a 30-minute meeting on 2025-10-21.

bob.goal: Provide my availability for scheduling a 30-minute meeting on 2025-10-21. Prefer minimizing interruptions to my morning schedule.

carol.goal: Provide my availability for scheduling a 30-minute meeting on 2025-10-21.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate the participants' availabilities and produce a PDDL domain and problem (targeting the FastDownward planner) that finds the earliest 30-minute meeting slot on 2025-10-21 when all are available, and if multiple slots are possible, choose the one that minimizes interruption to Bob's morning schedule.

public_information: Three colleagues need to schedule a 30-minute meeting on 2025-10-21 (Tuesday).
The goal is to find the earliest 30-minute time slot when all three are available.
If multiple valid slots exist, prefer the slot that minimizes interruption to Bob's morning schedule.

provide_availability.system_prompt: You are Alice. Provide your availability intervals for the meeting date in a concise machine-readable list of intervals. Do not produce PDDL. Use the private information you have.
provide_availability.prompt: Your name is alice. Public context: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->alice->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->alice->goal}. Output your availability intervals as a list such as ["09:00-11:00", "13:00-16:00"].

provide_availability.system_prompt: You are Bob. Provide your availability intervals for the meeting date in a concise machine-readable list of intervals. Do not produce PDDL. Use the private information you have and indicate any preference to minimize interruptions to your morning.
provide_availability.prompt: Your name is bob. Public context: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->bob->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->bob->goal}. Output your availability intervals as a list such as ["10:30-12:00", "14:00-15:30"]. If relevant, annotate which intervals are more sensitive to interruption.

provide_availability.system_prompt: You are Carol. Provide your availability intervals for the meeting date in a concise machine-readable list of intervals. Do not produce PDDL. Use the private information you have.
provide_availability.prompt: Your name is carol. Public context: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->carol->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->carol->goal}. Output your availability intervals as a list such as ["09:30-10:30", "11:00-12:30", "15:00-17:00"].

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent scheduling and PDDL planning for the FastDownward planner. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encode the scheduling task and allow FastDownward to find the earliest 30-minute slot on the given date when all participants are available. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep agent resources and actions distinct if modeling agent-specific constraints. The produced PDDL should explicitly target use with FastDownward.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You receive these availability artifacts: {alice_availability}, {bob_availability}, {carol_availability}. Public context: {environment->public_information}. Orchestrator goal: {agents->orchestrator->goal}. Construct a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that represent time slots on 2025-10-21 in units sufficient to model 30-minute meetings and participants' availability intervals. Encode constraints so the planner returns the earliest slot when all are available and, if multiple slots are possible, prefers the one that minimizes interruption to Bob's morning availability. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem>.
